docs.abstract: Europeans prefer Barack Obama to Mitt Romney, but, whoever wins in November, America is turning its gaze eastward.

headline.main: WellPoint to Acquire Amerigroup Amid Health Care Overhaul
headline.print_headline: WellPoint Will Buy Amerigroup to Expand in Medicaid and Medicare Markets

docs.abstract: The proposed acquisition demonstrates the increasing consolidation of health insurers as the federal health care law has put enormous pressure on companies in the industry to better control costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama will call for a one-year break only for people making less than $250,000, a limit opposed by Republicans and at odds with a higher cap favored by some Democrats.

headline.seo: Obama Seeks 2013 Tax Cuts Within Limits
headline.main: Obama Poised for New Fight With G.O.P. Over Tax Cuts
headline.print_headline: Obama Poised For New Fight Over Tax Cuts

docs.abstract: President Obama will call for a one-year extension of the Bush-era tax cuts for people making less than $250,000, a limit opposed by Republicans and at odds with a higher cap favored by some Democrats; by calling for an extension for just a year, he hopes to make Republicans look obstructionist and unreasonable and deepen the contrast with his challenger, Mitt Romney.
docs.snippet: President Obama will call for a one-year break only for people making less than $250,000, a limit opposed by Republicans and at odds with a higher cap favored by some Democrats.

docs.lead_paragraph: The region is engaged in a war over coal, with miners and their families pitted against environmental activists.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Jason Howard warns that residents of Appalachia are engaged in a heated debate over coal, particularly mountaintop removal mining, with miners and their families pitted against environmental activists; notes that the coal industry has succeeded in demonizing the environmentalists by saying regulation threatens jobs; calls on industry leaders and their elected allies to stop their propaganda and engage in an honest, civil dialogue about the health and environmental risks.
docs.snippet: The region is engaged in a war over coal, with miners and their families pitted against environmental activists.

docs.lead_paragraph: 6:05 P.M. (Cinemax) DIE HARD WITH A VENGEANCE (1995) Bruce Willis, left, starring once again as the-down-but-never-out cop John McClane, must stop another terrorist (Jeremy Irons) from destroying a public place. This time, however, Mr. Willis cannot get to the final ''yippee-ki-yay'' without some help from Samuel L. Jackson as Zeus Carver. The film leads its characters (and the viewer) on a dizzying tour of New York City during the mid-90s, from Harlem to Central Park and Wall Street and back up to Tompkins Square Park and the old Yankee Stadium. ''McClane and Zeus are plagued by fake bombs, real bombs and Simon's cadre of killers, not to mention cellular phones that suddenly go dead and really bad traffic on Ninth Avenue,'' Caryn James wrote in The New York Times. The film delivers, she added, ''pure action, with bigger and better explosions and stunts.'' 9:30 A.M. (AMC) RAY (2004) Jamie Foxx, right, won the best actor Oscar for his portrayal of the musician Ray Charles in this biopic directed by Taylor Hackford. A. O. Scott wrote in The Times that Mr. Foxx gave an ''inventive, intuitive and supremely intelligent performance.'' He added: ''He has mastered Charles's leg-swinging gait, his open-mouthed smile and the tilt of his head, as well as the speaking style that could sometimes sound like a form of scat singing. But there is much more than mimicry at work here.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Corporations are funding policy organizations that are free of the disclosure rules applying to parties, candidates and PACs.

headline.main: Tax-Exempt Groups Shield Political Gifts of Businesses
headline.print_headline: Groups Shield Political Gifts Of Businesses

docs.abstract: Review by the New York Times finds that many large corporations are trying to influence campaigns and policy decisions by donating money to tax-exempt organizations that can spend millions of dollars without being subject to the disclosure requirements that apply to candidates, parties and PACs; secrecy shrouding the groups makes a full accounting of corporate influence on the electoral process impossible.
docs.snippet: Corporations are funding policy organizations that are free of the disclosure rules applying to parties, candidates and PACs.
